    How To Use Swift‚Äôs Ternary Operator

    Ternary operators are beyond cool. They‚Äôre an easy way to do some if-else logic all on one line. Beyond that, they‚Äôre still easy to read and understand, so you don‚Äôt have to sacrifice readability for the ‚Äòcool factor‚Äô of using a language‚Äôs advanced features. In fact, it‚Äôs a great way to keep methods shorter and draw attention to other logic that may be more meaningful to your program.

    Start With An If-Else Statement

    Take the below code for example. You compare two variables, and print something based on the result.

    1
2
3
4
5

    if variable1 == variable2 {
    print("Equality! ü•≥")
} else {
    print("NO EQUALITY ü§¨")
}

    Convert It To One Line

    The ternary operator consists of 3 parts.

    1. A conditional check
    2. The result of the operation if the conditional is true
    3. The result of the operation if the conditional is false

    For our above if-else statement, we could write it like this üëá

    1

    print(variable1 == variable2 ? "Equality! ü•≥" : "NO EQUALITY ü§¨")

    Assigning A Value

    Ternary operations in Swift aren‚Äôt limited to just print statements. In fact, the ternary operator returns a value which can be used to set a variable.

    You could take the below check for the age to drink alcohol

    1
2
3
4
5
6
7
8
9

    var result = ‚Äú‚Äù

if(age < 21){  
  result = "Too young to drink üç∫"  
} else {  
  result = "Old enough to drink üçª"  
}

print(result)

    This is a lot of code to just assign a string based on a number value. We can use the ternary operator to do this in just 2 lines‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand you can see the example below üëá

    1
2

    let result = age > 21 ? "Too young to drink üç∫"" : "Old enough to drink üçª"
print(result)

    If you found this helpful, you might enjoy checking out my book on learning to program with Swift!
